spread.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if something spreads or is spread, it becomes larger or moves so that it affects more people or a larger area
spread.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Fire quickly spread through the building.
He watched the dark stain spread over the gray carpet.
The disease spread rapidly amongst the poor.
The cancer had spread to her liver.
Revolution quickly spread from France to Italy.
spread.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to become known about or used by more and more people
spread.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: News of the explosion spread swiftly.
The news spread like wildfire  (=very quickly).
Word spread quickly that she was leaving.
Buddhism spread to China from India.
spread.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to tell a lot of people about something
spread.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Andy loves spreading rumours about his colleagues.
They are spreading the word about the benefits of immunization.
spread.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to open something out or arrange a group of things so that they cover a flat surface
spread.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: a table spread with a white cloth
Papers and photos were spread across the floor.
He spread the map out on the desk.
spread.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to cover or exist across a large area
spread.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: the forest that spread over the whole of that region
The company has more than 2,500 shops spread throughout the UK.
spread.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to put a soft substance over a surface, or to be soft enough to be put over a surface
spread.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: If you warm up the butter, it’ll spread more easily.
Spread the nut mixture evenly over the bottom.
He spread plaster on the walls.
Spread the toast thinly with jam.
spread.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if you spread your arms, fingers, or legs, you move them far apart
spread.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: He shrugged and spread his hands.
spread.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to do something over a period of time, rather than at one time
spread.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: There will be 12 concerts spread throughout the summer.
Could I spread the repayments over a longer period?
spread.translation[0].definitions[8].def: to share or divide something among several people or things
spread.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: They want the country’s wealth to be more evenly spread.
The bills are sent out on different dates to spread the workload on council staff.
spread.translation[0].definitions[9].def: if an expression spreads over someone’s face, it slowly appears on their face
spread.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: A slow smile spread over her face.
spread.translation[0].definitions[10].de: if money, effort etc is spread thin, it is being used for many things so there is not enough for each thing
spread.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: They complained that resources were spread too thinly.
spread.translation[0].definitions[11].de: to try to do too many things at the same time so that you do not do any of them effectively
spread.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: a disease spreads/is spread
The disease is spread by mosquitoes.
a cancer/infection spreads
The cancer had spread to his brain.
news/word spreads
As news of his death spread, his army disintegrated.
spread the news/the word
He has been spreading the word about ways to beat heart disease.
spread a story
When Brown’s hotel burned down, Clark spread the rumor that Forsyth was to blame.
a story spreads
It was the sort of story that would spread like wildfire.
spread lies/gossip
How dare you spread such vicious lies!
Has someone been spreading malicious gossip?
spread terror/panic
The murders were clearly intended to spread terror.
fire spreads
The fire had spread to a nearby shed.
violence/fighting spreads
There is no indication that the violence is likely to spread.
somebody’s fame/reputation spreads
Their musical fame has spread far beyond their native country.
spread rapidly/quickly
The fire spread rapidly, consuming many of the houses.
spread like wildfire
The news spread like wildfire through the town.
spread.translation[1].definitions[0].def: when something affects or is known about by more people or involves a larger area
spread.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: an attempt to stop the spread of nuclear weapons
the rapid spread of cholera in Latin America
spread.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a soft substance made from vegetable oil that is used like butter
spread.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: one slice of toast with a low-fat spread
spread.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a soft food which you spread on bread
spread.translation[1].definitions[3].def: a range of people or things
spread.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: We have a good spread of ages in the department.
spread.translation[1].definitions[4].def: the total area in which something exists
spread.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: the geographical spread of the company’s hotels
spread.translation[1].definitions[5].def: a large meal for several guests on a special occasion
spread.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: Tom’s mum laid on a huge spread.
spread.translation[1].definitions[6].def: the area covered when the fingers of a hand, or a bird’s wings, are fully stretched
spread.translation[1].definitions[8].def: the difference between the prices at which something is bought and sold, or the interest rates for lending and borrowing money
spread.translation[1].definitions[8].exa: the spread between the city banks’ loan rates and deposit rates
spread.translation[1].definitions[9].def: the number of points between the scores of two opposing teams
spread.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to share work, responsibility, or money among several people
spread.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Companies may want to spread their equity widely among stable, long-term shareholders.
spread.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to pay for something gradually over a period of time
spread.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: I asked if I could spread out the repayments.
Spread your premium payments over 12 monthly instalments.
The cost is spread out over ten years.
spread.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to become widely used or known about
spread.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Deregulation is spreading across the whole of Europe.
spread.translation[2].definitions[3].def: to reduce the chance of a large loss by sharing the risk of insuring someone or something with other insurance companies
spread.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a range of people or things, especially investments
spread.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The bank is keen to broaden its spread of risks.
The assets represent a wide spread of fixed interest stocks, equity shares and property.
spread.translation[3].definitions[1].def: the difference between the interest rate a bank pays on DEPOSITs (=money put in the bank) and the interest rate it charges on loans
spread.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: Banks must maintain an adequate spread between borrowing and lending rates.
spread.translation[3].definitions[2].def: the difference between two rates of interest. Interest on company bonds is often set in relation to the interest on particular government bonds
spread.translation[3].definitions[2].exa: The noncallable notes were priced at a spread of 87.5 basis points  (=0.875%) over the yield on the Treasury’s 10-year note.
spread.translation[3].definitions[3].def: the difference between the buying price and the selling price of shares, UNIT TRUSTs etc
spread.translation[3].definitions[3].exa: The spread between the bid and ask prices for the options is ¼ to ½ point $25 to $50 an option.
spread.translation[3].definitions[4].def: the difference between the buying price and the selling price of a currency, or between two rates for a currency
spread.translation[3].definitions[4].exa: The policy of frequent devaluations of the Nicaraguan currency is designed to eliminate the spread between official and black-market exchange rates.
spread.translation[3].definitions[5].def: the difference between the price a financial institution pays to buy shares from the company that ISSUEs them (=makes them available) and the higher price the firm charges to investors who buy them
spread.translation[3].definitions[5].exa: The underwriting spread can range from 3.5% to 7% of the offering price.
spread.translation[3].definitions[6].def: in a MONETARY SYSTEM (=an arrangement where the values of currencies move in relation to each other within certain limits), the difference between the highest valued currency and the lowest
spread.translation[3].definitions[6].exa: The dollar remained the grid’s strongest currency, with the spread between it and the weakest currency widening to 11%.
